title: Syed Mohammad Ahsan
text:
<a href="Vice-Admiral">Vice-Admiral</a> Syed Mohammad Ahsan ( b. 1920 – d. 1990) , often known as S. M. Ahsan, was a <a href="Three-star%20rank">three-star</a> rank admiral in the <a href="Pakistan%20Navy">Pakistan Navy</a>, politician, and the <a href="Commander%20in%20Chief%20%28Pakistan%20Navy%29">Commander in Chief of the Pakistan Navy</a>, serving under President <a href="Ayub%20Khan%20%28general%29">Ayub Khan</a> from 1966 until 1969.
After that, he briefly served in President <a href="Yahya%20Khan">Yahya Khan</a>'s administration as <a href="Finance%20Minister%20of%20Pakistan">Finance minister</a> before becoming Governor of <a href="East%20Pakistan">East Pakistan</a> in September 1969 until resigning in March 1971 to return to Pakistan. Gaining a commission in the <a href="Royal%20Indian%20Navy">Royal Indian Navy</a>, he participated as a naval officer during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> with the British and later decided to become a Pakistani citizen following the <a href="Partition%20of%20India">partition</a> of <a href="India">India</a> by the United Kingdom in 1947. He played a crucial role in establishing the <a href="Inter-Services%20Intelligence">Inter-Services Intelligence</a> and served in the <a href="Indo-Pakistani%20war%20of%201965">war</a> with India in 1965. Assuming the <a href="Chief%20of%20Naval%20Staff%20%28Pakistan%29">naval command</a> in 1966, he took initiatives such as establishing the naval <a href="Special%20Service%20Group%20Navy">special forces</a>, expanding the capabilities of <a href="Naval%20Intelligence%20of%20Pakistan">Naval Intelligence</a> and modernising the navy.
He was a trusted colleague of President Ayub Khan while attending the <a href="Cabinet%20of%20Pakistan">cabinet meetings</a> chaired by President Ayub which enabled him influentially consolidate his <a href="National%20Security%20Council%20%28Pakistan%29">national security</a> role in the Ayub administration. After completing his tenure as naval chief, he was appointed as <a href="List%20of%20Governors%20of%20Pakistan">Governor</a> of East Pakistan while serving as a cabinet minister in the Yahya administration.
On 1 September 1969, Vice-Admiral Ahsan assumed as the Governor of East Pakistan until his resignation, in protest, on 7 March 1971. He was then posted back to Pakistan.
Biography.
Early life and World War II.
Syed Mohammad Ahsan was born in <a href="Hyderabad%20Deccan">Hyderabad Deccan</a>, <a href="British%20Raj">Indian Empire</a>, to an <a href="Urdu%20speaking">Urdu-speaking</a> <a href="Hyderabadi%20Muslim">Hyderabadi</a> <a href="Syed">Syed</a> family in December 1920. After being schooled in <a href="Hyderabad%20india">Hyderabad</a>, he attended the <a href="Nizam%20College">Nizam College</a> of the <a href="Osmania%20University">Osmania University</a> and gained <a href="Bachelor%20of%20Arts">B.A. degree</a> and decided to join the <a href="Royal%20Indian%20Navy">Royal Indian Navy</a> (RIN) in 1938 as a <a href="Sub%20lieutenant">Sub-Lieutenant</a> when his <a href="first%20cousin">first cousin</a> <a href="Captain%20Muhammad%20Jalaluddin%20Sayeed">M.J. Syed</a> joined the <a href="Indian%20Merchant%20Navy">Royal Indian Merchant Navy</a>.
In 1938, he was accepted to join the <a href="Britannia%20Royal%20Naval%20College">Britannia Royal Naval College</a> in United Kingdom where he was trained, and after a short probationary period in <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a>, he was given commission as <a href="Lieutenant%20%28navy%29">Lieutenant</a> in Executive Branch of the Royal Indian Navy. He specialized in <a href="Signals%20intelligence">Signals</a> and was an instructor at the <a href="Combined%20Cadet%20Force">Combined Cadet Force</a> in Liverpool, England.
During <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> he was a RIN <a href="naval%20officer">naval officer</a> on the side of Great Britain and saw actions in the <a href="Battle%20of%20the%20Atlantic">Atlantic battle</a> against the <a href="Kriegsmarine">German Kriegsmarine</a>. Upon posting back to <a href="British%20Indian%20Empire">British India</a>, he participated in <a href="Arakan%20Campaign%201942%E2%80%9343">Arakan Campaign</a> in 1942–43 and later served well in the <a href="Mediterranean%20and%20Middle%20East%20theatre%20of%20World%20War%20II">Mediterranean theatre</a> in 1944–45. His actions of valor earned him to be decorated with the <a href="Distinguished%20Service%20Cross%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Distinguished Service Cross</a> by the United Kingdom after the <a href="End%20of%20World%20War%20II%20in%20Asia">end of World War II</a> in 1945.
In 1946, he was appointed as <a href="aide-de-camp">aide-de-camp</a> to Viceroy of India, <a href="Louis%20Mountbatten%2C%201st%20Earl%20Mountbatten%20of%20Burma">Lord Mountbatten</a> and assisted him in <a href="1946%20Cabinet%20Mission%20to%20India">cabinet meetings</a> to resolve political crises in the British Indian Empire.
When the United Kingdom <a href="Indian%20Independence%20Act%201947">announced its intentions</a> to <a href="partition%20of%20India">partition of India</a> in 1947, Ahsan decided to <a href="Pakistani%20citizenship">opt</a> for <a href="Pakistan">Pakistan</a> and was introduced by Lord Mountbatten to <a href="Muhammad%20Ali%20Jinnah">Muhammad Ali Jinnah</a> as his aide-de-camp. In a meeting with Jinnah, Lord Mountbatten reportedly quoted: [President] Jinnah, I give you Pakistan, I give you my Aide'd camp, Lieutenant Ahsan."
At the time of his joining the <a href="Pakistan%20Navy">Pakistan Navy</a>, the <a href="Indian%20Navy">Indian Navy</a> sent the military seniority list to Pakistan's <a href="Ministry%20of%20Defence%20%28Pakistan%29">Ministry of Defence</a> (MoD) where Lt. Ahsan was the 4th ranking officer in the Executive Branch in terms of seniority with <a href="Service%20number">Service No.</a> PN-007. He was assigned as military adviser and <a href="Aide-de-camp">ADC</a> to <a href="Founder%20of%20Pakistan">founding father</a> and the first <a href="Governor%20General%20of%20Pakistan">Governor-General</a> M.A. Jinnah. In 1947, Lt. Ahsan was the first person at the <a href="Jinnah%20Terminal">Jinnah Terminal</a> to receive Lord Mountabattens when they first arrived to Karachi to meet Jinnah. He did not participated in the <a href="Indo-Pakistani%20War%20of%201947">first war</a> with India on <a href="Kashmir%20problem">Kashmir crises</a> in 1947.
On 30 September 1949, he witnessed the commissioning of the <a href="PNS%20Tippu%20Sultan%20%28D49%29">PNS "Tippu Sultan"</a> from the <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a> and was subsequently promoted as <a href="Lieutenant-Commander">Lieutenant-Commander</a>. He was made First <a href="Executive%20officer%20%28military%29">Executive officer</a> of <a href="PNS%20Tippu%20Sultan%20%28D49%29">"Tippu Sultan"</a> and later <a href="Commanding%20officer">commanding</a> the <a href="PNS%20Tariq%20%28D129%29">PNS "Tariq"</a> as <a href="Commander%20%28naval%29">Commander</a> in 1950. He participated in <a href="Task%20Force%2090">Task Force 92</a> alongside with Commander <a href="Afzal%20Rahman%20Khan">A.R. Khan</a> who commanded the "Tippu Sultan" and made a first goodwill visit to <a href="Malta">Malta</a>, Middle East and Eastern Europe. In 1951, he commanded the which became a part of the 25th Destroyer. In 1955–56, he was posted in the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Defence%20%28Pakistan%29">MoD</a>'s diplomatic assignment as the <a href="Naval%20attach%C3%A9">Naval attaché</a> at the <a href="Embassy%20of%20Pakistan%2C%20Washington%2C%20D.C.">Pakistan Embassy</a> situated in the Washington D.C.– the <a href="state%20capital">state capital</a> of the United States. During this time, he went to attend the <a href="Naval%20War%20College">Naval War College</a> in <a href="Newport%2C%20Rhode%20Island">Newport</a> in <a href="Rhode%20Island">Rhode Island</a>, graduated with a <a href="Staff%20%28military%29">staff course</a> degree from the <a href="Naval%20War%20College%23College%20of%20Naval%20Command%20and%20Staff">College of Naval Command and Staff</a> of the <a href="Naval%20War%20College">Naval War College</a>.
In 1957, he was promoted as <a href="Captain%20%28naval%29">Captain</a> and assigned to command the <a href="Cruiser%20%28warship%29">cruiser warship</a>, the <a href="HMS%20Diadem%20%2884%29">PNS "Babur"</a>, that sailed in <a href="Karachi">Karachi</a> the following year.
Staff and command appointments.
His first assignment included his role as Deputy Director of <a href="Naval%20Intelligence%20of%20Pakistan">Naval Intelligence</a> at the <a href="NHQ%20%28PN%29">Navy NHQ</a> while establishing his intelligence department.
At December 1952, he was asked by Director General of the Inter-Services Intelligence Major-General <a href="Robert%20Cawthome">Robert Cawthome</a> to send a priority report that compiled detail discussions with <a href="Pakistan%20Armed%20Forces">Pakistani military</a> personnel on the basic principles of the <a href="ISI%20%28Pakistan%29">ISI</a>. In addition, he was also asked for military's reaction towards the <a href="Basic%20Principles%20Committee">Basic Principles Committee</a> where he ultimately warned of the <a href="theocracy">theocracy</a> and concluded that the economic disparities between <a href="East%20Pakistan">East</a> and <a href="West%20Pakistan">West</a> Pakistan must be addressed to prevent the <a href="Breakup%20of%20East%20and%20West%20Pakistan">breaking-up</a> of the nation's <a href="Faith%2C%20Unity%2C%20Discipline">unity</a>. In 1959–60, he served as <a href="chief%20of%20staff">chief of staff</a> of the <a href="NHQ%20%28PN%29">Navy NHQ</a> under the <a href="Commander%20in%20Chief%20%28Pakistan%20Navy%29">Navy Commander in Chief</a>.
In 1960, he was promoted to the <a href="One-star%20rank">one-star</a> rank, <a href="Commodore%20%28rank%29">Commodore</a>, and directed the Naval Intelligence during this time. In 1961–62, he again served on the diplomatic assignment when he was appointed as deputy chief military planning officer of <a href="Southeast%20Asia%20Treaty%20Organization">Southeast Asia Treaty Organization</a> (SEATO) in <a href="Bangkok">Bangkok</a> and later became its chief military officer.
In 1962, he was promoted as <a href="Rear%20Admiral">Rear Admiral</a> and established the <a href="Pakistan%20Navy%23commands">Logistics Command</a> to resolve the <a href="Military%20logistics">logistics</a> problems in both East and West Pakistan. In 1964, he was sent to <a href="Dacca">Dacca</a> and took over the chairmanship of the <a href="Bangladesh%20Inland%20Water%20Transport%20Authority">East-Pakistan Inland Water Transport Authority</a> where he had begun training of <a href="Bangladesh%20Armed%20Forces">East-Pakistani military</a> on <a href="riverine%20warfare">riverine tactics</a> with the absence of the strong naval presence. During this time, he became the principal <a href="Military%20Secretary%20%28Pakistan%29">military secretary</a> to President Ayub Khan. In a short time, Rear-Admiral Ahsan gained influence on President Ayub Khan and advised him on important military issues concerning on the defence of the nation at the cabinet meeting chaired by the President Ayub.
While in East, he played a crucial role in deployment of armed forces and prevented the army to involve in politics while opposing any military action against East Pakistani activists after the <a href="1964%20East%20Pakistan%20riots">riots</a> in 1964 despite the calls.
1965 war with India and Commander in chief.
In 1965, he was stationed back to Pakistan and assumed the command of Naval Intelligence as its <a href="Director-General">Director-General</a>, and participated in <a href="Indo-Pakistani%20war%20of%201965">second war with India</a> in 1965. Rear-Admiral Ahsan and his staff at the <a href="Naval%20Headquarters%20%28Pakistan%20Navy%29">Navy NHQ</a> helped planned out the <a href="Operation%20Somnath">naval offense</a> in <a href="Dwarka">Dwarka</a> and partially leading the fleet as its Commander. The operation met with mixed results but it stopped the <a href="Indian%20Air%20Force">Indian Air Force</a> raiding Karachi and Pakistan's coastal areas as Admiral Ahsan collated the intelligence reports on the Indian Navy's strategic western naval positions, and orchestrated naval operations against the Indian Navy.
After the war, he was most senior admiral serving in the navy and was nominated for navy's <a href="chief%20of%20staff">chief of staff</a> by outgoing <a href="Chief%20of%20Naval%20Staff%20%28Pakistan%29">naval chief</a> Admiral <a href="Afzal%20Rahman%20Khan">A.R. Khan</a> in 1966. His nomination papers were approved by President Ayub Khan in 1966, and appointed him as <a href="Commander%20in%20Chief%20%28Pakistan%20Navy%29">commander in chief</a> of <a href="Pakistan%20Navy">Navy</a>.
In 1967, he was promoted to the three-star rank, <a href="Vice-Admiral">Vice-Admiral</a>, and was honored with <a href="Sitara-e-Pakistan">Sitara-e-Pakistan</a> by President Ayub.
As a naval chief, he oversaw the induction of the <a href="PNS%20Hangor">Daphné</a> submarines procured from France in 1966 in navy's submarine branch. In 1966, he held successful negotiation with <a href="Turkish%20Navy">Turkish Navy</a> to <a href="Refitting">refitted</a> and <a href="Mid-life%20update">upgraded</a> the submarine <a href="PNS%20Ghazi">PNS "Ghazi"</a>.
Since 1966–68, Admiral Ahsan knew of Indian Navy massive <a href="Future%20of%20the%20Indian%20Navy">procurement and acquisitions</a> of <a href="Weapon%20systems%20of%20the%20Indian%20Navy">weapon systems</a> being acquired from the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a> and United Kingdom. On multiple meetings with President Ayub, he raised the issue of modernizing the navy against India, and kept warning the <a href="GHQ%20%28Pakistan%20Army%29">Army GHQ</a> of potential and possible Indian Navy's attack on <a href="West%20Pakistan">West</a> and <a href="Eastern%20Pakistan">East</a> region of the country; his reservations were bypassed on every meeting and warnings were not heed due to the financial reasons. His Navy NHQ staff was in brief conflict with the <a href="Air%20Headquarters%20%28Pakistan%20Air%20Force%29">Air AHQ</a> staff over the establishment of <a href="Pakistan%20Naval%20Air%20Arm">naval aviation</a> by induction of fighter jets in 1968. The <a href="Air%20Headquarters%20%28Pakistan%20Air%20Force%29">Air AHQ</a> staff bypassed his recommendation over the loss of jets and their pilots in seas in an event of conflict with India. He succeeded in convincing President Ayub in acquiring the missile boats only, and permissions were granted to procured the Soviet-built <a href="Osa-class%20missile%20boat">Osa-class missile boat</a> in 1968.
He led series of unsuccessful talks with the <a href="Soviet%20Navy">Soviet Navy</a> and Russian Marshal <a href="Andrei%20Grechko">Andrei Grechko</a> in 1969 due to their <a href="Indo-Soviet%20Treaty%20of%20Friendship%20and%20Cooperation">warming</a> of relations with India. From 1966 to 1969, his <a href="NHQ%20%28Pakistan%20Navy%29">Navy NHQ</a> staff tussle with the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Finance%20%28Pakistan%29">Finance ministry</a> over the issues of budget and financial support for modernization of navy without any success.
He established the <a href="Special%20Services%20Group%20Navy">Special Services Group Navy</a> (SSG[N]) and commissioned the <a href="Pakistan%20Marines">Pakistan Marines</a> in 1966 after commissioning the naval <a href="PNS%20Qasim">facilities</a> for training purposes in the <a href="Special%20Operations%20Forces">special operations</a>.
In 1966, he further accepted the recommendation from <a href="United%20States%20Navy">United States Navy</a> to train its special forces unit, an equivalent organization to that of <a href="U.S.%20Navy%20SEALs">U.S. Navy SEALs</a>.
In Karachi, he went on to commission the <a href="Pakistan%20Naval%20Academy">Naval Academy</a> to provide teaching of the naval staff and cadets instead of sending cadets to United Kingdom for training and education. From 1966 to 1968, he served on the served on the <a href="Board%20of%20Governors">Board of Governors</a> of <a href="Cadet%20College%20Petaro">Cadet College Petaro</a>.
Vice-Admiral Ahsan is also credited with founding <a href="Port%20Qasim">Port Qasim</a> – Pakistan's second port – after exploring the coast around <a href="Phitti">Phitti Creek</a>, when he was Chief of Naval Staff. He immediately met with then–Foreign Minister <a href="Zulfikar%20Ali%20Bhutto">Zulfikar Ali Bhutto</a> where he convinced Bhutto in 1972 to locate the port there.
After convincing Bhutto, he supervised the construction and establishment of the port where he set up the main industries and machineries at the Port. The main channel of this port bears his name. From 1966 to 1969, he established the <a href="Bangladesh%20Navy">East-Pakistan Navy</a> and commissioned the <a href="warship">warship</a>s, "PNS <a href="Sylhet">Sylhet</a>" and <a href="PNS%20Tughril%20%28D167%29">"PNS Tughril"</a>, in its arm. However, he struggled with expanding the East-Pakistan Navy's capabilities as many sailors and officers had defected to India to joined the <a href="Awami%20League">Awami League</a>'s military wing– the "<a href="Mukti%20Bahini">Mukti Bahini</a>".
Politics.
Yahya administration and governorship.
After President <a href="Ayub%20Khan%20%28general%29">Ayub Khan</a> tendered resignation due to worsening of <a href="Law%20and%20order%20in%20Pakistan">law and order</a> situation in the country, and invited <a href="Commander-in-Chief%20of%20the%20Pakistan%20Army">Commander-in-Chief of the Pakistan Army</a> General <a href="Yahya%20Khan">Yahya Khan</a> to take over the <a href="Pakistani%20presidency">presidency</a>. In 1969, he relieved the <a href="Commander%20in%20Chief%20%28Pakistan%20Navy%29">naval command</a> to Admiral <a href="Muzaffar%20Hassan">Muzaffar Hassan</a> to be appointed as deputy <a href="Chief%20Martial%20Law%20Administrator">CMLA</a> under <a href="Yahya%20Khan">Yahya administration</a>.
In August 1969, he joined the Yahya administration as <a href="Cabinet%20of%20Pakistan">cabinet minister</a> of <a href="Ministry%20of%20Finance%20%28Pakistan%29">finance</a>, <a href="Ministry%20of%20Statistics%20%28Pakistan%29">statistics</a>, <a href="Ministry%20of%20Commerce%20%28Pakistan%29">commerce</a>, <a href="Ministry%20of%20Industry%20%28Pakistan%29">industry</a>, and <a href="Planning%20Commission%20%28Pakistan%29">planning commission</a>. However, this was short-lived and Admiral Ahsan was appointed as Governor of East Pakistan on 1 September 1969.
The assignment was considered very difficult by the <a href="Pakistani%20military">Pakistani military</a> when many senior officials in West were reluctant to accept appointments in East Pakistan. The <a href="Law%20and%20order%20%28politics%29">law and order</a> situation was quickly deteriorating under the <a href="Military%20coups%20in%20Bangladesh">martial law</a> enforced by <a href="Major-General">Major-General</a> Muzaffaruddin in <a href="East%20Pakistan">East</a>.
In the Cabinet meeting, <a href="Yahya%20Khan">President Yahya</a> was told that the situation in East is at a critical, and his government needed an administrator with a good reputation in the province. In an attempt to control the <a href="Law%20and%20order%20in%20Pakistan">law and order</a> in the country, Admiral Ahsan's service was extended and appointed governor in East and arrived his <a href="Dhaka">Dacca</a> to take an oath from <a href="Dhaka%20High%20Court">Dhaka High Court</a> Justice Salahuddin at the <a href="Dhaka%20University">Dhaka University</a> in 1969. In talks with representatives of Pakistani print and electronic news media, Admiral Ahsan reportedly quoted that he was "pretty sure" that by 1971, new government of elected representatives would replace the interim government."
He became governor of East Pakistan in 1969. Soon after, he was reportedly in conflict with Governor of West Pakistan, Air Marshal <a href="Nur%20Khan">Nur Khan</a>, over the issues of <a href="Legal%20Framework%20Order%2C%201970">legal and political</a> reforms in the country while President Yahya was in conflict with his army chief Lieutenant-General <a href="Abdul%20Hamid%20Khan%20%28general%29">Abdul Hamid Khan</a> on administrative issues in 1969–70.
Many initiatives were taken by Admiral Ahsan to resolve the political crises of East by keeping in good terms with President Yahya and noted that the <a href="Six%20point%20movement">six-point</a> were not new. In 1969, he paid a <a href="state%20visit">state visit</a> to the United States to meet with <a href="Elliot%20Richardson">Elliot Richardson</a> to gain foreign support for East Pakistan and sustainability in the region. In addition, he also arranged the visit of U.S. Navy officials to visit him at the <a href="Bangabhaban">Governor's House, Dhaka</a> to <a href="Pakistan%E2%80%93United%20States%20military%20relations">strengthened military relations</a> with the United States.
In 1970, his government coordinated efforts to rehabilitate the infrastructure after the <a href="1970%20Bhola%20cyclone">deadly cyclone</a> and used the military coordinate to relief operations after meeting with President Yahya who had instruct him to "take charge".
1970 general elections, resignation and 1971 war.
In 1970, he oversaw the electoral process to hold the nationwide <a href="1970%20Pakistani%20general%20election">parliamentary elections</a> held in the country in a charged atmosphere. Under his rule, the law and order had been improved and it was projected that Awami League led by <a href="Sheikh%20Mujibur%20Rahman">Sheikh Mujibur Rahman</a> would claim the <a href="supermajority">supermajority</a> in the <a href="Bangladesh%20parliament">provincial assembly</a> that would allow them to form the national government in <a href="Islamabad">Islamabad</a>. The Awami League secured ~39.2% of the seats in the <a href="Parliament%20of%20Pakistan">Parliament</a> as opposed to the <a href="Pakistan%20Peoples%20Party">Pakistan Peoples Party</a> (PPP) led by <a href="Zulfikar%20Ali%20Bhutto">Zulfikar Ali Bhutto</a> who ended up with 18.6% of the seats – all from West Pakistan. Zulfikar Bhutto refused to negotiate the <a href="Six%20point%20movement">six points</a> when President Yahya met with Sheikh Mujibur Rahman and put more stress on the situation after telling his party workers not to visit Dhaka. About the postpone of the power ceremony, <a href="Kamal%20Hossain">Kamal Hossain</a> reportedly notified Admiral Ahsan of "danger" of delaying the power transition.
Together with his principal staff officer Lieutenant-General <a href="Sahabzada%20Yaqub%20Khan">Sahabzada Yaqub Khan</a>, he provided his arguments on numerous occasions to President Yahya against the <a href="Operation%20Searchlight">military actions</a> in East and their arguments were well known to the United States's politicians.
On 22 February 1971, Ahsan attended a high-level meeting chaired by President Yahya Khan, a gathering which Ahsan described as "tense", where the atmosphere was highly "anti-Bengali", with no Bengali representation in the policy and decision-making. He opposed a military solution to the supposed crisis in East Pakistan.
Admiral Ahsan renewed his offer to President Yahya, Rahman, and Bhutto to work out an arrangement where the Pakistani military deployments to support the <a href="Pakistan%20Eastern%20Command">Eastern Command</a> could get out intact, without <a href="Instrument%20of%20Surrender%20%281971%29">being humiliated</a>. Known as the Ahsan Formula, Pakistan would become a confederation of the two wings, giving East Pakistan a degree of autonomy. Yahya would head the confederation. East Pakistanis in West Pakistan would be moved to East Pakistan and vice versa. National assets would be divided in proportion to population. The military vetoed the plan.
In February 1971, he supervised the military deployments in East that were already preparing to conduct a military operation to curb the movement.
Disheartened and isolated by his colleagues, Admiral Ahsan tried reaching President Yahya by telephone without success. On 7 March 1971, Admiral Ahsan resigned in protest from his position as Martial Law Administrator of East Pakistan.
He participated in the <a href="Indo-Pakistani%20war%20of%201971">war</a> with <a href="India">India</a> in 1971 but without an assignment of any command at the <a href="NHQ%20%28Pakistan%20Navy%29">Navy NHQ</a> and sought <a href="honorable%20discharge">honorable discharge</a> from the navy after the <a href="Instrument%20of%20Surrender%20%281971%29">war ended</a> in the winter of 1971.
In an article titled "A nation's shame" published in the "Newsline magazine" of September 2000, Ahsan concluded:
But who was responsible for creating this hostile atmosphere and hatred among the people? The situation deteriorated further after General Yahya Khan postponed the first session of the newly elected constituent assembly. It became very clear immediately after the election results that the generals were not prepared to transfer power to the Awami League. First the delay in summoning the National Assembly session and later its postponement confirmed the Bengalis' worst fears, that the election results were not acceptable both to the generals and to the majority of West Pakistani politicians. Zulfikar Ali Bhutto publicly called for a boycott of the assembly session. Such a transgression was bound to further fuel public resentment.
War Enquiry Commission.
He welcomed the formation of the <a href="Hamoodur%20Rahman%20Commission">War Enquiry Commission</a> that was to be chaired by <a href="Chief%20Justice%20of%20Pakistan">Chief Justice</a> <a href="Hamoodur%20Rahman">Hamoodur Rahman</a> in 1972, and attended its proceedings. He testified before the commission and described the hostile mood of the military leadership when they decided to postpone the assembly session and launch a military operation in the eastern province. Ahsan stated:
On arrival in Rawalpindi, I was alarmed to notice the high tide of <a href="militarism">militarism</a> flowing turbulently... There was open talk of a military solution according to plan. I was caught quite unaware in this atmosphere for I know of no military solution which could possibly solve whatever crisis was supposed to be impending in the minds of the authorities. It was evident from the statement that the decision to launch a military operation was taken without consulting the Governor of East Pakistan who was the only sane voice in the government.
The President presided over the meeting of the governors and martial law administrators attended as usual by the military and the civilian officers of the <a href="Pakistani%20Intelligence%20Community">intelligence community</a>. It is relevant to record that among the tribe of governors and MLAs, I was the only non-army governor and the only active naval officer in the midst of active service men. I was the only person, though a non-Bengali, who had to represent the sentiments of seventy million Bengalis to a <a href="Pakistani%20government">Pakistani government</a>. During the past 17 months, in meetings and conferences, my brief ran counter to the cut-and-dried solutions of Pakistan representatives and civil servants. The president invariably gave decisions which accommodated East Pakistan's viewpoint, at least partially. This made me unpopular with my colleagues who probably thought I was "difficult at best" and "sold" to the Bengalis at worst.
Legacy.
post-retirement, death and honours.
Ahsan retired from the Navy.
He was appointed chairman of Port Qasim Authority in 1972 and later chairman of <a href="Pakistan%20National%20Shipping%20Corporation">National Shipping Corporation</a> from 1975 to 1976. After leaving the public service in 1976, he spent his remaining years in quietness and put himself out of public eye during his last years. During his last years, Admiral Ahsan learned French and played bridge.
Ahsan died peacefully in 1989 in his Karachi villa and was given an honorary <a href="guard%20of%20honor">guard of honor</a> by the <a href="Government%20of%20Pakistan">Government of Pakistan</a> and buried in military graveyard in Karachi per accordance to his will. His death was mourned by Prime Minister <a href="Benazir%20Bhutto">Benazir Bhutto</a>, President <a href="Ghulam%20Ishaq%20Khan">Ghulam Ishaq</a>, <a href="Chairman%20Joint%20Chiefs%20of%20Staff%20Committee%20%28Pakistan%29">Chairman joint chiefs</a> Admiral <a href="Iftikhar%20Ahmed%20Sirohey">Iftikhar Ahmed Sirohey</a>, and Chiefs of Staff of <a href="Chief%20of%20Army%20Staff%20%28Pakistan%29">Army</a>, <a href="Chief%20of%20Naval%20Staff%20%28Pakistan%29">Navy</a>, and <a href="Chief%20of%20Air%20Staff%20%28Pakistan%29">Air Force</a>.
In 1990, the Pakistan Navy established a <a href="naval%20base">naval base</a> in <a href="Balochistan%2C%20Pakistan">Balochistan</a> and commissioned in 1991 as <a href="PNS%20Ahsan">PNS Ahsan</a> to honor his services.
The main channel of the <a href="Port%20Qasim">Port Qasim</a> bears his name, as it known as Ahsan Channel, which was inaugurated by Prime minister <a href="Benazir%20Bhutto">Benazir Bhutto</a> who acknowledged Admiral Ahsan's as the founder of Port Qasim at a speech on the occasion of the opening of a new terminal at Port Qasim on 4 August 1989.
